poem:
**Captivity's Echo**

The world shrinks to a cell,
pale light sifting through bars of sand.

She waits for Keith,
a shadow at the edge of hope,
the sky knotted with the wings 
of a thousand unsent birds.

Freedom is not the lack of walls,
but finding each other
again,
in the open field of morning.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Freed Israeli hostage Aviva Siegel on a ‘terrible’ war strategy and waiting for her husband to come home A former hostage whose husband is still captive in Gaza said she doesn’t expect to see him again unless Israel agrees a ceasefire deal. Aviva Siegel was freed after 51 days in captivity, under a week-long agreement last November. Her fears for her husband, Keith Siegel, are sharpened by her own ordeal of hunger, deprivation, violence, isolation". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
